div.p: FALSE IMPRESSIONS: A COMEDY IN FIVE ACTS. PERFORMED At the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden. BY RICHARD CUMBERLAND, ESQ.

q.l: Saepe, etiam audacem, fugat hoc terretque poëtam;
Quod numero plures, virtute et honore minores,
Si diſcordet eques, media inter carmina poſcunt
Aut urſum aut pugiles: his nam plebecula gaudet.

div.p: London: PRINTED FOR C. DILLY, IN THE POULTRY, 1797. [Price 2s.]

lg.l: THE time hath been, but in a barbarous age,
When poets brav'd their audience from the ſtage,
Poets pontifical, whoſe lofty tone
Acknowledg'd no tribunal but their own,
And ſent their Prologue-purveyor to raiſe
Firſt fruits and fines of tributary praiſe.
Our modern bards are taught an humbler ſtrain,
And, if leſs valiant, are not half ſo vain;
No longer aim the nation's taſte to lead,
Content if they can follow and ſucceed.
Thus if the time ſhould come, when in the place
Of Nature you ſhou'd ſubſtitute grimace,
(Fatal reverſe!) What cou'd the Poet do?
Offend the many to appeaſe the few?
No, if in Greece true taſte had been as ſcarce,
The Stagyrite himſelf had ſtood for farce.
If wit thro' five long acts will not hold out,
Momus muſt help to ſtir the laugh about,
And when you crown his mummery with applauſe,
You bribe him to tranſgreſs the drama's laws.
He were a very wild romantic elf,
Who only wrote to figure on the ſhelf;
To hear his own ſad ſentiments rebound
Thro' empty galleries with a dying ſound,
And ſit like Seneca in calm decay,
Watching how life ſteals drop by drop away:
No, let him take his profit and his eaſe,
And trifle on ſo long as trifles pleaſe:
Too weak to ſtruggle againſt faſhion's tide,
If with the current he's content to glide,
He only yields as Caeſar did before,
When Tiber's torrent drove him from the ſhore.
The ſimple tale we have to tell this night,
Shews truth triumphant over ranc'rous ſpite,
Caſts in dark ſhades the baſe defamer's part,
And crowns with juſt reward the liberal heart.
Oh might our efforts gain their wiſht for end,
The gay to' amuſe, the faulty to amend,
Make fiction rule her thoughts by nature's laws,
And wit exert her powers in virtue's cauſe,
Then and then only might we claim applauſe.

div.stage: SCENE, a Chamber in the Houſe of SCUD the Apothecary.

sp.p: AHA! very good, very good. Here I am again—no bad night's work—pretty fairiſh job—patient none the better, myſelf none the worſe—tipt two guineas for ſitting up with old Lady Cypreſs—ſlept comfortably in an eaſy chair— nibbled a cold chicken with my Lady's woman— tiff'd a can of flip with the old butler—crib'd a kiſs or two from the ſweet lips of Mrs. Rachel, and gave her a box of cardamums and a bottle of elder-flower water in return for the favour—So far, ſo good—Well done, Jerry Scud!—Holloa! Jack, boy, puppy! where are you?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Here am I, maſter.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p:
Fetch my ſlippers, ſirrah! Take off my boots. Exit JACK. My dear Jenny can't abide boots; very right, very reaſonable; ſoil the carpet, dawb her petticoats, annoy her olfactories—No wonder—delicate
darling my Jenny—ſweet pretty creature—perfect poſey of a woman— Re-enter JACK. So, ſo, ſo! take hold, ſirrah; pull away! That will do, that will do—ſet my flippers—red moroccos— ſtockings not ſoil'd—pretty well off there—Now, puppy Jack, where's your miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Don't know.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: How does ſhe do?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Can't tell.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Is ſhe at home?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: An't ſure.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Was ſhe at home laſt night, or was ſhe out?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Both: ſometimes in, ſometimes out.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: You're a fool. Had ſhe company?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: No, no; no company.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Poor dear Jenny! What, quite alone?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: No, no; not quite alone.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Jackanapes, didn't you tell me ſhe had no company?

sp.speaker: Jack.
sp.p: Yes I did; becauſe why? ſhe bade me let no company in; yet ſhe wasn't quite alone by herſelf, becauſe young Squire Algernon was alone with her.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: The devil and his dam! I'm done for. Get out of my fight! begone! away with you!
Ah Jenny, Jenny, Jenny! You are bent upon ſending your poor huſband to heaven ſome day or other, when it rains while the ſun ſhines—How now, Peter!

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Is there any alteration to be made in Lady Cypreſs's medicines?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: None at all, none; draughts ſicut ante.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: They do no good.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: They do no harm.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: They are a mere chip in porridge—Conſerve of roſes will never cure an aſthma.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: I know it; what then? A patient cur'd is a cuſtomer loſt. In one word therefore, repetatur hauſtus.

sp.speaker: Peter.
sp.p: Be it ſo! let nature do the work herſelf; our practice wont puzzle her.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Miſerable man that I am; my Jenny tête-a-tête with Harry Algernon!—a rake, a rogue, a rantipole. Hah! here ſhe comes—
Light of my eyes, joy of my heart, fair as a lily, come to my arms! Out all night—ſigh'd for my darling—counted the minutes—terrible long abſence—how did you bear it?—Doubt you've been loneſome—

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Not at all; far from it. Harry Algernon has been here.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: What does he want? Nothing to ſay to him.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: But you'll hear what he has to ſay to you.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Let him ſay it to me only. Not fit company for jewel Jenny.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Ridiculous! He only wants a little of your intereſt with Lady Cypreſs.—Apropos! he has brought you half a buck.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Let him take his half buck home again. Wou'dn't name his name to Lady Cypreſs for all the veniſon in his father's park.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p:
Hav'n't you nam'd his name to Lady
Cypreſs? I doubt you have, Jerry, oftener than you ought, and in a way you ſhou'd be aſham'd of.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Only ſaid what lawyer Earling ſaid—always had the law o' my ſide.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: On which ſide was truth? on which ſide was gratitude? Recollect yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: What ſhou'd I recollect?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: I'll tell you.—Your adventure at Barnſtable races, when in the pride of your heart you muſt ſhew off in your new gig forſooth; and where wou'd you have been now if the very man you have defam'd hadn't ſav'd your life at the peril of his own?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: He did, he did—I don't deny it. Tit run reſtive—tipt me over a wheelbarrow—tumbled under his heels—might have been kick'd to atoms— ſurgeon's work as it was—ſnapt my arm—well it was not my neck—much obliged to Harry Algernon—never ſpoke againſt him ſince.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Speak for him, man; 'tisn't enough you do not ſpeak againſt him: liberate your conſcience.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Jenny, Jenny, liberate my conſcience, as you call it, and I ſhall liberate my cuſtomers; if Harry Algernon will be a rantipole; if his women and his wine, his racing and his revelling, have croſs'd him out of the old lady's books, how am I to blame?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Well, well, 'tisn't your buſineſs to ſet the worſt ſide of his character to view; you have benefited by his courage and humanity—why don't you talk of them, and hold your tongue about his frailties?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p:
My tongue can do nobody any harm.
I tell you it is all up with him: lawyer Earling has done his buſineſs. If ever he enters my lady's doors, or touches a ſhilling of her fortune while he breathes, ſet me down for a fool and a falſe prophet.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Suppoſe he does not aim at touching a ſhilling of her fortune; ſuppoſe he only wants— but here he comes, and will tell you what he wants.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Ah, Jerry, my worthy fellow, give me your hand, give me your help.—No, no, that's not the point at preſent—take your fingers off my pulſe.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Very high, let me tell you—very full— gallops at a furious rate.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Expectation raiſes it, hope quickens it; love is my diſeaſe; and if you don't ſtand my friend, diſappointment will be my death.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Love! Can't cure love—troubled enough to cure the conſequences of it.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Hark ye, Jerry, you are an intimate of Lady Cypreſs; I, though her neareſt of kin, am an exile. Within her caſtle lives the idol of my ſoul, Emily Fitzallan; obtain for me an interview with her, and though you can't cure love, you may reſcue me from death, and then you may fairly boaſt of having ſav'd one man's life by your practice.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Can't do't—not poſſible—fair Emily never goes out of the caſtle.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Therefore it is I want to go into it.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Hopeleſs caſe—not upon the chances— Old Lady won't bear to look upon you.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p:
I'll excuſe her if I may but look upon the young one: manage that for me, my good fellow.—
Nobody knows me; nobody can find me out; I'm a ſtranger to the whole family.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: And ſo you are likely to remain.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Come, come, Jerry, caſt about; be good natur'd, and contrive ſome errand or pretence to introduce him. If there is a little danger, ſurely you may riſque it for the preſerver of your life.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Fooliſh ſcheme, jewel Jenny, fooliſh ſcheme.—Won't do.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Have you no medicines to ſend in? Can't I perſonate your peſtle and mortar-man?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Not you; I keep no ſuch peſtle and mortar-man in my ſhop.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: But you keep a heart in your body, and a memory in your brains, therefore you muſt ſtand for me as I have ſtood for you.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Huſh! here comes Simon Single, the keeper of the caſtle. Leave me with him, and I warrant I have a key to his caſtle.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Angel of my hope, into your hands I commit my cauſe.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Aye, aye, leave your cauſe, and quit your company.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Welcome, welcome, my good friend!

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Glad to ſee you, pretty Mrs. Jane.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: So you are taking your rounds this fair morning, Mr. Simon.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Better take them than Jerry's doſes.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: I agree with you.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: So wou'd not they perhaps.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p:
And how are all cronies at the caſtle? How does the venerable virgin Mrs. Buckram,
pretty Rachel Williams, and the reſt of the fair nuns?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Name 'em not; you have not left your fellow. What is Rachel Williams? a baby.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Well, but Mrs. Buckram—ſhe is no baby.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: No, o' my word; ſhe is of the race of the Anakims.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: No matter for that, friend Simon; you'll marry Buckram.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: No, no, that buckram ſhall never ſtick in my ſkirts. Harapha of Gath wou'dn't marry her. I am no knight-errant to encounter giants.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: I ſhou'd think ſo; for if you were a true knight, you wou'd not ſleep before you had ſet free your lovely priſoner, Emily Fitzallan.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: There's one a-coming will do that. Fair Emily will be a wife before you'll be a widow. Young Montrath is the man for her; he's expected every day with his uncle Sir Oliver. It is all agreed upon, and my lady's whole fortune will be ſettled on Miſs Emily. There's a ſtart for you—there's a ſally from dependance to proſperity; from wanting every thing to poſſeſſing all.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: And nothing left to Harry Algernon?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Yes, patience if he poſſeſſes it, and an ill-name whether he merits it or not.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Well, I can't ſee the juſtice of all this.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p:
Who can, where lawyer Earling is concerned? That puppy of an attorney lords it over the whole caſtle; and now we are in the buſtle of ſetting out Miſs Emily in a ſtile before Sir Oliver arrives. There are fine dreſſes to be made, fine
apartments to be furniſhed, and freſh ſervants to be hir'd for the heireſs.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Say you ſo? freſh ſervants? Are you full? If not, I can recommend you ſuch a lacquey—the very man of men—Jerry ſhall bring him to you.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Bring him yourſelf; lead him over in a white bridle, and let me judge of his points and his paces.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: You ſhall—my life for your's, Miſs Emily will be charm'd with him.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Adieu! time flies when I am with you. Once more, adieu! I ſhall expect you. I hope you are happy with your little doctor; but I muſt think you were much too fine a flower to be pluckt by an apothecary, and ſtuck into a gallipot.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: He's off; you may come out of your hiding hole; the coaſt is clear.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Now, my fair advocate, what have you done for me? Is there any hope?

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Of the old lady's fortune, none; your aunt has not left you a ſhilling.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I'm glad of it.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: I wonder why.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Miſs Emily is to have the whole.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for it.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: I wonder wherefore.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I'll tell you then. Had my aunt bequeath'd to me her fortune, ſhe wou'd have probably reſtricted me from marrying Emily; having given it to Emily, ſhe has doubtleſs tied her up from marrying me. Had ſhe done neither one nor the other, I have enough to maintain her, and the prize had been my own.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: And ſo ſhe ſhall; I've a project for your meeting.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I doubt if I ought to ſeek it.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Very true; lay it aſide altogether; it will bring a plaguy deal of miſchief upon me, and do no good to you.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Tell it me however.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: You'll comprehend it at once. There is a proper valet to be hir'd for the heireſs, fit to wait upon her perſon, and grace the back of her chair at table.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I can't do it; I am not equal to the taſk; I can't approach ſo near, and yet refrain. When ſhe ſpoke to me, I ſhou'd be loſt; when ſhe look'd on me, I ſhou'd betray myſelf; and when I handed her the plate, I ſhould preſent it on my knee.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Aye, then you wou'd be vollied out of the window, and I kick'd out of the doors. Now, ſilly Jenny, what's become of your project?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Hold there! tho' dangerous in the extreme it is not altogether deſperate. If I cannot undertake the offices you deſcribe, I may yet preſent myſelf as a candidate for her ſervice; and in that character perhaps obtain an interview with my charmer. That hope is worth an effort.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: It isn't worth a farthing, and will be pounds and pounds out of my way. Curſed ſcrape, fooliſh Jenny, curſed ſcrape!

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: But where ſhall I get a proper dreſs to appear in?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: No where; you can't appear at all.

sp.speaker: Jenny.
sp.p: Fear nothing; I'll provide you with a dreſs.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Egad, ſhe has a proviſion for every thing.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Who but muſt conquer that is armed by the fair? There is a raſcal in the family, Earling by name, who has ſlanderouſly defam'd me; I'll wring his ears from his head.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Take care; Earling is an attorney, and if he has any ears you will pay for wringing them; if he has none, you'll be puzzled to lay hold of them.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Come, Jerry, I ſee what ſtaggers you; you are afraid of loſing the old lady's cuſtom.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: You are right; I am. She takes phyſic, and you take pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Mark me! I'll not promiſe you to ſwallow as many medicines as ſhe does; but, come what will, I'll guarantee you againſt all loſſes incurr'd on my account; ſo fear nothing, but come on. Diſcretion I can't boaſt of, but in honour I will never be found wanting.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: That's enough, that's enough! Deal upon honour and I am with you. I love to do a good natur'd action when there's nothing to be loſt by it.

div.stage: SCENE changes to an Apartment in Lady CYPRESS's Caſtle.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Enter, enter, Mr. Earling: you come upon a wiſh.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Ever prompt to approve myſelf your ladyſhip's moſt devoted and moſt abſolute humble ſervant, upon a wiſh I come, upon a word I vaniſh.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: I am ſatisfied with your diligence; you may ſpare yourſelf the trouble of deſcribing it.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: I am dumb.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Have you the memorandums about you, that I dictated?

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: If my tears have not defac'd them. Believe me, gracious lady, when I ſaw my own name ſet down to a bequeſt ſo munificent, I was cover'd with bluſhes, I was choak'd with gratitude.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Out with it then, out with your name, if ſuch is the effect, and write in Algernon's; I warrant gratitude will not choak him.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Good, very good! Your ladyſhip has the gift of rallying me in the moſt pleaſant way out of my metaphors. Choak is a figure ſomewhat of the ſtrongeſt.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Why yes, and I ſhou'd think you may venture upon the legacy, and riſque the effects of it; ſo copy out your paper when you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: I'll ſet my clerks upon it out of hand.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: You'll ſet the world upon it when I'm out of it, for you have totally caſhier'd Harry Algernon, and he is the ſon of my ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: And your ſiſter was the wife of his father, and his father was your unremitting perſecutor, who vex'd you with a ſuit in chancery for ten long years, and ten might have been added to ten, had it not been that I—I ſpeak modeſtly of myſelf; I am no egotiſt—I ſpeak ſimply of number one, and nobody elſe, for your barriſter was a cypher—

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: But a cypher put to number one adds no trifle to its value; ſo the upſhot is, you gain'd the ſuit, and I paid the coſts—a victory little to be envied—and, after all, is it juſt and equitable the ſon ſhould ſuffer for the father's faults?

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: O jus et aequum! as if he had not faults enough of his own to warrant your excluſion of him.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: I have heard enough of his faults I confeſs, if you are correct in deſcribing them. If you have deceiv'd me—

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: I! I deceive you! I defame your nephew! I who have never ſpoke of his offences but with regret and ſorrow; never brought a ſtory to your ears, but with the view of intercepting malice and ſoftening down impreſſions; I deceive you! then where is truth and virtue?

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Both in ſight, as I ſhou'd hope—for Emily appears.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: I humbly take my leave. Miſs Emily, I'm your's—Humph! not a word! Your faithful friend to ſerve you. Not a look? Upſtart! I'll marry the old lady, and cut her out of every ſhilling—I will.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Approach, my dear! Come near me. I muſt talk with you. Well! You have been to ſee the apartment I have newly furniſhed—and do you like it, Emily?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: 'Tis elegant in the extreme—'tis ſumptuous.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: 'Tis your's, my dear; it is to grace my Emily that I have deck'd it out.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: For me ſuch finery?

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Child of my heart, for you. All I poſſeſs is your's.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I hope you will not tempt me to forget that I was poor and humble.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: I hope not: nature has endow'd you with admirable qualities; proſperity, I truſt, will not pervert them. It does not quite come on you by ſurprize: you cou'd not well ſuppoſe I ſhou'd adopt the ſon of my moſt unrelenting perſecutor.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I did not dare to reaſon in that caſe.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: But you muſt know how worthleſs in himſelf, how undeſerving of my favour is he, who, in reſpect of conſanguinity, is the only perſon that cou'd ſuperſede you.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: You ſpeak of Mr. Algernon.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: I do; I ſpeak of him, whom no one ſpeaks of but with reproach and ſcorn.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I do confeſs I've heard much evil ſpeaking, but 'twas from one who ſhou'd have more reſpect for truth and decency than to traduce the nephew to the aunt.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: What do you mean? Wou'd you defend a libertine?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: No, madam, I defend no libertine; but you will not be angry if I avow that I deteſt a libeller. If he, who thus has poiſon'd your opinion, knows not the character, the manners, habits, ſentiments, connections, perhaps not even the outward form and feature of the man, whoſe fame he mangles, can I be to blame if I implore you, for the love of juſtice, to hear before you ſtrike?

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: What is this, Emily? What is this warmth?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Honeſt, not prudent; out of time and place, but ſtill ſincere, tho' raſh.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p:
You call on me to hear before I ſtrike; I now demand if you that ſtrike have heard?
Do you know Algernon? Have you convers'd with him?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Madam, I have.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: You have! when, where? he comes not hither; never was admitted, never will be, within theſe doors. Aſtoniſhing that you ſhou'd dare to tell me you have made acquaintance with this profligate.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Hear my defence.—You gave me leave to paſs a little time, for change of air after my late confinement, at your Hill-farm. One evening I had rambled about a mile from home, when upon entering a little copſe, thro' which my footpath led, judge of my horror, when a villain, ſuch I muſt call him, ſurpriz'd me, ſeiz'd me, and in ſpite of cries, prayers and entreaties—

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Merciful providence! what do you tell me?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: A dreadful tale I ſhou'd have had to tell, or died ere I cou'd tell it, had not heaven ſent me a reſcue, a brave brave preſerver, who with a ſoul all fire, and motion quick as lightning, ſprung on the aſſailant, graſp'd him in his arms, and after a contention, furious tho' ſhort, hurl'd him to the ground, breathleſs, and maim'd with bruiſes.— Which of theſe merits the name of profligate? Not be that ſav'd me—It was Algernon.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Algernon do you ſay? My worthleſs nephew Algernon! Take care!

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Renounce me if I tell you an untruth.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: I'm all aſtoniſhment. Who was the aſſailant?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
Madam, I know not. Your heroic
nephew bore me half dead and fainting to my houſe; 'twas not till then I knew him to be Algernon. He ſtaid with me no longer than till the care of the good people had recovered me: the next morning I return'd to the caſtle, fearing to remain any longer in ſo ſolitary a place. Of Algernon, I ſaw no more. Now ſuffer me to aſk, is this the conduct of a profligate?

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſtrange ſtory.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: 'Tis a true one, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Why have you kept it to yourſelf thus long? You've been return'd two days.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Becauſe until this hour I have not ſeen your ſpirits in a ſtate to bear the ſlighteſt agitation.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: And do you think the agitation ſlight that I now ſuffer? No, I ſee your danger, Emily; I ſee your weak credulity, and much I fear you'll find yourſelf the dupe of Algernon. What buſineſs cou'd he have at my Hill-farm?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Madam, your tenant's wife nurs'd Mr. Algernon.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: She never ſhou'd have nurs'd you, Emily, or harbour'd you one moment, had I known it.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: That's hard; but I muſt ſuffer and be ſilent.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Be ſilent then, and go to your chamber; there you may meditate on what you have been, and call to mind, with timely recollection, what you may be again.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Caſte Hall.—SIMON SINGLE, Farmer GAWDRY, and his Son ISAAC.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: MASTER Gawdry, Maſter Gawdry, have I not ſaid the word, and will not the word that I have ſaid ſerve and ſuffice to put thee out of doubt, that Iſaac thy ſon, thy ſon Iſaac, will not do?

sp.speaker: Gawd.
sp.p: I pray you now, Maſter Simon Single, be kind-hearted, and conſider of it. I ſhou'd be main proud to have him in my lady's livery; he's a docile lad, and can turn his hand, as I may ſay, to any thing.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Let him turn it to the plough; he's a bumpkin: let him drive the team and dung the land; he's born to it: let him ring the hogs, and tend the ſtye, and toil in the drudgery of his vocation. Nature never faſhion'd him to be the lacquey of a lady—You are anſwer'd, farmer Gawdry.

sp.speaker: Gawd.
sp.p: Aye, Maſter, I am anſwer'd, but I am not heard. I hann'a told you half the things my boy can do.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: What can he do? Unfold!

sp.speaker: Gawd.
sp.p: A power—Speak for yourſelf, Iſaac; tell the gentleman what you can do.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: A'looks ſo grave, a'daunts me.

sp.speaker: Gawd.
sp.p: What ſhou'd daunt thee, boy? Don't hang thy head, but up, and tell him boldly what can'ſt do.

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: I wull, father, I wull.—I can ſing pſalms, ſhoot flying, worm the puppies, cut capons, climb the rookeries, and make gins for polecats.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Wonderful! and can't you eat and drink, and ſleep and ſnore abundantly? Can't you wench when you have an opportunity, ſwear now and then upon occaſion, and lie a little when it ſerves your purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Iſaac.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I know ſomething of all theſe matters.

sp.speaker: Gawd.
sp.p: I told you he was fit to wait upon any lady in the land.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Upon any lady but the lady Cypreſs he is welcome; upon her he may wait long enough before he gets any other anſwer than I've given you. Dictum eſt—Good morning to you.

sp.speaker: Gawd.
sp.p: Good morning to me indeed! How long, I trow, have you been this great man, to carry yourſelf in your geers ſo ſtately? I can call to mind the day when you came into this family as mere a bumpkin as you think my boy to be.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Keep your temper, neighbour Gawdry, keep your temper; mount your ſteed, amble homewards, viſit your oves and your boves, comfort your good dame, and preſent my humble ſervice to her.

sp.speaker: Gawd.
sp.p:
I won't comfort her; I won't preſent your humble ſervice to her; I don't find you are ſo willing to do her any ſervice, and as for humble, it don't belong to you—but mark my words—time is at hand—county election's coming on—aſk me for a plumper then, do; aſk me, I ſay, for a plumper
—and mind where I'll direct you to look for it. Come along, Iſaac, come along!

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: We men in power; when we have a place to give away, make nine enemies to one friend, and 'tis nine to one if that friend don't turn an enemy before he is well warm in his office.—Ah, Doctor, is it you?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Your ſervant, your ſervant! I have brought you the young man Jenny recommended.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Have you ſo, have you ſo? Where did you fall in with him?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Croſs'd upon him by mere chance—clever fellow—wants a place—think he'll ſuit Miſs Emily— no objection, dare ſay, on his part—won't haggle for wages—will you ſee him?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Hold a moment.—Has he got a character?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Two—a good one and a bad one; but the good one is what he wou'd prefer being known by.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: I give him credit for that. What name does he bear?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Henry, alias Harry—you may take your choice.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: He has two of them, it ſeems; very good! What beſides?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Scudamore.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: A branch of the Scuds we'll ſuppoſe; but we'll ſee him.—Where does he come from?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p:
T'other ſide of the country—better let
him anſwer queſtions for himſelf—come in, young man; preſent yourſelf to Mr. Simon Single, the reſpectable major domo of this illuſtrious family.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: So, ſo! what's here? This is no drudge for all work and all weathers; this is a thing for Sundays and for holidays! as clean a peg to hang a livery on as heart cou'd wiſh.—Well, Henry Scudamore, you're for a place, and, I conclude, one where there's leaſt to do will pleaſe you moſt; you are not us'd to labour.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I am not.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Nor ever mean to be, I dare believe.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Oh fie! you'll put him down; he's modeſt to a fault.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: If that's his only fault, we'll overlook it. What can you do?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: My beſt to pleaſe my miſtreſs, and ſomething, I ſhould hope, to gain your favour.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Egad, you've found the way to that already; I like your anſwer much; I like your manners, countenance, deportment; and I am no mean judge, altho' I ſay it.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Sir, you have all the right in life to ſay it; for if none elſe will give us a good word, we muſt e'en praiſe ourſelves.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: A ſharp wit, let me tell you.—Harkee, Henry, your name I know; the place from whence you come I do not know; your qualifications remain to be prov'd, and your character I dare ſay, if it is of your own giving, will be an excellent good one.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: With your leave I ſhou'd prefer to ſpeak upon all theſe points with the lady I aſpire to ſerve.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Aſpire to ſerve! Sir, your moſt obedient humble ſervant.—I ſhall aſpire to aſk you no further queſtions, but turn you over for examination to the lady of the houſe herſelf.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Is this the lady of the houſe now approaching?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Of the lower houſe ſhe is the lady. Make your beſt bow to Mrs. Dorothy Buckram, but don't be too aſpiring; if you offer to ſalute her you are a loſt man; that bleſſing don't fall to my lot above once in a twelvemonth, and ſome would not aſpire even to that.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What is this ribaldry that you are talking? and who is this young man?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: A youth of promiſe; a candidate for ſervice; one that aſpires to the ſupreme delight of carrying clogs and combing lap-dogs for the lady heireſs.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What is his name.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Henry.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: A gentle name, ſoothing and ſoft, I much approve of Henry: I've ever had a prejudice for Henry.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Simon is ſweeter.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Jerry is more briſk.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Sweet Simon—ſimple Simon—why 'ts muſic—it is a lute.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: But Jerry ſounded in F ſharp's a trumpet.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Yes, truly, in the ears of a hen-peck'd huſband when his partlet cackles.—But can't this youngſter ſpeak? Henry ſhou'd ſpeak like Henry; let us hear you. Were I the miſtreſs you aſpir'd to ſerve, what wou'd you ſay to me?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Silence becomes a ſervant; 'tis a virtue; but if I were your equal and your lover.—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ah, then what wou'd you ſay?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Then if you ſtood all tempting as you are, full in my ſight, and cheer'd your happy ſwain with ſmiles ſo lovely, languiſh ſo alluring.—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What wou'd you do?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I'd ſnatch you to my heart, preſs you, careſs you, ſmother you with fondneſs.—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: And ſo you will; let go, or I'll ſcream out.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Bravo; you'll do—A very good rehearſal.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: A very villanous one, if my Jenny has had a part in it.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: I give you joy, young man; your fortune's made.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: I wonder who has taught him this aſſurance.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Oh madam, he's a pupil of my Jenny's; I've nothing to do with him.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Come, come, there's no offence; t'was a fair challenge, and no true Engliſhman wou'd have refus'd it.—Courage, my lad! you'll never want a ſervice. Let us adjourn.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Well, now you've heard the ſtory, what do you ſay to it?

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: What, nothing? then you don't believe it.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Pardon me, madam; I believe it happened juſt as Miſs Emily relates it to you; I do believe there was a man ſet on to frighten her, and that he took a drubbing from her hero, for which I alſo perfectly believe he was well paid.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Why ſhou'd you not ſuppoſe it might be real? there are ſuch drunken fellows up and down.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: But ſober men will not be taken in by ſuch ſtale tricks. You meet the ſame, or ſomething very like it, in even paltry novel that you read. The man's eſcap'd; you'll never hear of him; his bargain was not made to go to priſon.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: I ſee it now; I ſee thro' the contrivance.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Yes, madam, and you may alſo ſee which way your property will go, if ever Miſs has the diſpoſal of it.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: I'll never ſign thoſe deeds in her behalf till ſhe conſents to marry as I'd have her. Indeed, indeed, you have ſav'd me, my good Sir, from a moſt raſh and inconſiderate meaſure.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Now is the time; I'll ſeize the happy moment.—My ever honour'd lady, I but live to ſave and ſerve you; my whole life has been devoted to your happineſs; the founder of your fortune, I have fought your battles manfully, and ſtood a ſiege as long as that of Troy in your defence; aye, and wou'd die in it if need requir'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: There is no need—I know your ſervices, and at my death you'll find I have not underrated them.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: She melts—I'll ſtrike.—Not at your death, dear lady, (may that be far, far off!) but with your life reward me.—Hah! that tells ſhe yields to the impreſſion.—

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: How with my life? You have my good opinion; you have my friendſhip; what more can I do for you?

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Think of me only as I think of you. Why ſhou'd a thankleſs girl engroſs your fortune? Uſe it; employ it; many happy days are yet in ſtore for you. When the Lord Cypreſs married you he was your ſenior by a pretty many years more than your ladyſhip is mine.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Your inference from that?

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: I dare not quite reveal it. I wou'd wiſh your ladyſhip to take it to your thoughts. A hint, a word, a look, ſo it were kind, wou'd greatly help me to declare it to you.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: We'll talk no more at preſent, if you pleaſe; you will remember you're my agent, Sir; and I will not forget your ſervices.—Good day to you.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: May every day and every hour be happy as I cou'd wiſh them, and you will be bleſt.—'Twill do—her pride is dropping from the perch—ſhe totters; I ſhall catch her.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: How now, Simon! have you found a proper lad amongſt the tenants ſons to ſerve Miſs Emily?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Of them not one, ſo help me, honor'd lady—I cannot recommend them; they are boors, clowns, clodpates.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: What is to be done?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: There is a youth attending—Doctor Scud ſpeaks in his favour.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Scud's a babbler.—What do you ſay?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: He is above the level of theſe indigenous ſmock-frocks and hobnails. I ſhou'd adviſe your ladyſhip to ſee him.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: By all means; let him enter.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Henry, you are permitted to approach: the Lady Cypreſs deigns to look upon you—make your obeiſance!

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: So! this is the young man—Henry you call him; what other name belongs to him?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Scudamore, an pleaſe you; ſo he gives in himſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: No vulgar name—and, ſo far as appearances beſpeak, no vulgar perſon. Well, Henry Scudamore, you want a place.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I wiſh to ſerve your ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Have you been in ſervice?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: So I ſhou'd gueſs. What leads you now to ſeek it?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: The ambition of belonging to your ladyſhip; but I wou'd anſwer more directly, might I preſume.—

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: I underſtand you. Simon, leave the room. Exit SIMON. You ſeem embarraſs'd. Was it not your wiſh to ſpeak to me in private?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Madam, it was.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: And what have you to impart, that one, who poſſibly may be your fellow ſervant, might not be privy to?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Madam, I am a gentleman by birth; that being known amongſt my fellow ſervants might chance to raiſe an evil mind againſt me, and make my humble ſtation painful to me; your candour will not think the worſe of me becauſe I am unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: No, not the worſe in charity of thought, but I cannot employ you in my ſervice. No gentleman muſt wait upon that lady, to whom I elſe perhaps had deſtin'd you. —No gentleman at leaſt of your appearance.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for it—but it is my fate to be judg'd by appearances, and condemn'd by reports.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: If you have fallen into this decay by mere misfortune, or injurious treatment, I can pity you; nay, Henry Scudamore, if that's your name, and if I knew your ſtory (which at preſent I have not time to hear) I cou'd do more—I cou'd (and ſomething whiſpers me I wou'd) conſider your neceſſities, and help you.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I am the victim, madam, of a villain. My ſtory is ſoon told, for it is founded on a ſimple fact, which I can make appear to full conviction, if you will condeſcend to give me hearing, and ſuffer me to ſtate ſuch evidence, as cannot be oppos'd by my defamer.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: I know not what to ſay to that, young man; I have no ſtrength to ſpare for other's burthens, and am already loaded with my own, even to the breaking down of my weak frame. If 'tis a caſe of pity, I've a hand that's open to your wants without enquiry; if it is matter of grievance and redreſs, I wou'd recommend you to ſtate it to my lawyer, Mr. Earling, and he ſhall ſee you righted.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I humbly thank you; I will ſtate it to him, and truſt the goodneſs of your heart will ſee me righted.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p:
Ah! I've no heart, no health, no nerves to hear you. You muſt excuſe me, Henry
Scudamore. I dare not undertake to arbitrate; but wait Sir Oliver Montrath's arrival, and he ſhall hear you; he's a noble gentleman.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Where ſhall I wait the whilſt?

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Where? Let me ſee—yes, you may ſtay this night here in the caſtle. My old ſervant, Simon, will entertain you at the ſecond table. Does that content you?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I were moſt unthankful if it did not.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Follow me then, and I will give my orders.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Rachel!

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Madam! what are your commands?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Don't anſwer me in that ſtile. I have ſo long been a dependant, and liv'd in ſuch familiarity with you, my good Rachel, in particular, that, tho' you are my ſervant, I don't wiſh you to uſe a language to me ſo ſubmiſſive.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Whatever language you wou'd have me uſe, ſo it will but convey the ſame reſpect, I will endeavour to conform to it.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I wou'd fain keep upon ſuch terms with fortune, that I may fall back to my former poverty without a pang; therefore, if ever you perceive me giddy with proſperity, recal my recollection to the low ſituation I emerg'd from, and do it honeſtly, my girl; don't ſpare me.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: You'll want no monitor to warn you againſt pride, and yet, as you require ſincerity, there is one warning I conceive is needful juſt at this criſis.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: State it without reſerve.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Are you not now in danger of incurring your patroneſs's moſt ſevere diſpleaſure?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Perhaps I am; but be explicit with me.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Your champion Algernon, has he not left a thorn in that ſoft heart?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: If you call gratitude a thorn, he has.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Are you quite ſure 'tis only gratitude? May it not ſoon be love? Nay, give me leave— is it not love already?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Well, if it is, how can I ſtrive againſt it?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Prudence will tell you how.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Prudence will tell me an old goſſip's tale, but who, that is in love, will hear her out?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Are you aware how fatal it will be to all your expectations, if my lady diſcovers your attachment?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Are you aware how natural it is to love the man who ſaves you from deſtruction? My lady gives me riches, Algernon reſcues my life and honour; I was loſt but for his courage; I am only poor without her bounty; and if ſhe demands that I ſhou'd ſacrifice my heart's affections, ſhe makes conditions that I cannot grant, nor wou'd her fortune bribe me to the attempt.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Do you know Mr. Algernon's character?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
Does he that blackens it? What does my lady know but what that lawyer inſtils into her ear? Infamous man! And why does he defame him? why, but becauſe he may retain his power in the eſtate, and garbel it at pleaſure? Beſides, he has an ample legacy; believe me, I hold it a diſgrace to read my name in the ſame page with his; nor wou'd I be his partner in the crime of plundering
Algernon, but that I live in hopes the time will come when I may render back the unlawful ſpoil.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Then temporize the whilſt, my deareſt lady, or that time never will be your's.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: 'Tis right; you counſel well; and now I will confide a ſecret to you: I have warn'd Algernon who is his enemy, and what baſe ſtories have been forg'd againſt him.—Ah! who is this? 'Tis he, 'tis he himſelf!

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Huſh! not ſo loud.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Your name was on my lips. How came you here? How did you gain admiſſion, and what have you in view by this diſguiſe? You may diſcloſe; this friendly girl is ſecret.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Then let her ſtay; I wou'd not be ſurpriz'd in private with you. I am here by ſufferance of Lady Cypreſs; I have ſeen my aunt for the firſt time, convers'd with her, and lodg'd a plea for further hearing when her friend, Sir Oliver Montrath, ſhall be at leiſure: one of his ſervants is already come; he may be ſoon expected.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And his nephew, does he accompany him?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I did not aſk that queſtion of the ſervant, but if you wiſh it I will make the enquiry.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: No, let it paſs. I know your aunt expects him.—Hark, Rachel, ſomebody is at the door —ſee who it is.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Madam, there's nobody, nor any ſound that I can hear.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Stand where you are and liſten!—What is the meaning of this dreſs you wear?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p:
I put it on to counterfeit a ſervant, or, I ſhou'd rather ſay, to aſk for ſervice—Will you not
try me, Emily? don't take my character from that attorney; I'll ſerve you honeſtly.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: You ſerve! you're jeſting.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Am I not your ſervant? I am your faithful ſervant.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: My heroic preſerver—that is your rightful character, and by that title you have a claim upon my gratitude, which only can expire with life— and now inform me what you have in view by this adventure.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I am not ſo romantic as to think I can maintain my poſt longer than till to-morrow, to which time I have a furlough by authority; if fortune ſtands my friend I may effect ſomething within that period; but even now am I not ſupremely bleſt to ſee you, hear you, and behold that face, that was of late ſo pale and wan with terror, reſtor'd to all the luſtre of its charms?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: That face, aſſure yourſelf, will never be turn'd from you to league with thoſe who ſeek to rob you of your fame and fortune.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I am not robb'd of what enriches you.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: The heart, that ſwells with indignation againſt all that wrong you, had but for you been cold and motionleſs.—

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Oh Emily, forbear.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: This and no more—I never will be made the ſlave of intereſt or dupe of ſlander. My confidence in you cannot be ſhaken, my obligations cannot be computed. The life that I poſſeſs is of your giving—What can I ſay but that I live for you?— Now leave me, Henry; not a word, but leave me.

sp.speaker: LADY CYPRESS.
sp.p: HARK! 'tis the porter's bell—run to the hall, and tell me if Sir Oliver's arriv'd.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Madam, he's here: Sir Oliver is preſent.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Welcome, moſt welcome! May I truſt my ſenſes? This is above hope that you and I ſhould live to meet again.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: My ever dear, my ever honour'd lady!

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Time has gone lightly over you, my friend! You, that have travers'd ſea and land, are whole; I, that have tempted neither, am become a ſhatter'd wreck on ſhore.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Not ſo, not altogether ſo, thank heaven! Time is a ſurly gueſt, whoſe courteſy does not improve by long acquaintance with us; but we'll not rail at him ſince he permits us once more to meet.—And here's the ſame old caſtle ſtill unſpoilt by modern foppery; aye, and the ſame old grand ſires firm in their frames with not one wrinkle more than when I parted from them years ago.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Aye, years indeed—but you have fill'd them up with glory; your's has been a life of themes for future hiſtory, a field of laurels to adorn your tomb—mine has been tame and ſimple vegetation.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p:
I have liv'd a ſoldier's life; but, heaven
be thank'd, I've plunder'd no nabob, ſtript no rajah of his pearls and pagodas, nor have I any blood upon my ſword, but what a ſoldier's honour may avow—but you have here a relict of my gallant comrade major Antony Fitzallan. He was wounded by my ſide, carried off the field, and died in my arms. With his laſt breath he bequeath'd ('twas all he had to beſtow) a bleſſing to his daughter, and charg'd me, if I liv'd to come to England, to thank you for your charity, and be a friend to her.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: I truſt you'll find her worthy of your friendſhip.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Is ſhe good, is ſhe amiable? Has ſhe her father's principles, her mother's purity?

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: See her and judge; ſhe's naturally ſincere—but where's your nephew? where is Mr. Lionel? — I reckon'd with much pleaſure upon ſeeing him.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Ah, my good lady, there I am unfortunate. I had built upon the hopes of preſenting him to you; but it cannot be at preſent. Poor Lionel is indiſpos'd, and muſt bear his diſappointment with what philoſophy he can.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: The diſappointment is reciprocal—a little time I hope will bring him to us.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: I wiſh it may—but look! who comes—

sp.speaker: Lady Cypr.
sp.p: This is my orphan charge—This is our Emily.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: The very image of her lovely mother.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: My dear, this is Sir Oliver Montrath, mine and your father's friend; as ſuch you'll honour him.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: As ſuch I claim the privilege to embrace and preſs her to my heart. My child, my charge, devolv'd upon me by a father's legacy, when breathing out his gallant ſoul in prayers and bleſſings for his Emily.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Oh ſir, was you, was you beſide him at that dreadful moment?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: I was, my child! theſe arms ſupported him, cover'd with wounds, and crown'd with victory—alas! how dearly purchas'd.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Then let his laſt commands be ever ſacred; if you have any ſuch in charge to give me, impart them, I conjure you.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: I have none but bleſſings to impart. In fortune's gifts the hero had no ſhare, in virtue's he abounded. In the care of this your generous benefactreſs he had left you; to that and heaven's protection he bequeath'd you.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I am content; and what before I ow'd in gratitude to this beneficent and noble lady, I now will pay with filial obedience and duty ſuperadded. Suffer me, deareſt madam, from this moment to call myſelf your daughter.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: As ſuch I have adopted you; remember now, my child, the duty you have taken on yourſelf, the authority you have conſign'd to me. All rights parental center now in me; your happineſs, your credit, your eſtabliſhment, are truſts for which I am reſponſible.—You have no other taſk but to obey.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Obedience, madam, has its limitations; but ſuch as I would render to my father I'll pay to you. Have I your leave to withdraw?

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: You may, my dear; your ſpirits ſeem to need it.—Go and compoſe yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Exquiſite creature! I'm enchanted with her. By heaven! 'twould be the heighth of my ambition, the object I have moſt at heart in life, to ſee my Lionel—Oh that I cou'd!—here kneeling at her feet.—Born of ſuch parents, train'd by ſuch inſtructions, and grac'd with charms ſo lovely, Emily, without a fortune, is a match for princes.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: If ſuch is your diſintereſted wiſh (and greater happineſs I could not pray for) I truſt my fortune thrown into her ſcale will not make her appear leſs worthy of your nephew, or cauſe you to retract your good opinion.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: No, ſurely; but I doubt if I ſhould wiſh your fortune to go out of the right channel even to Emily. We that have never married ſhould regard our nephews as our ſons.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: But does affinity impoſe on me an obligation to beſtow my property on one that merits nothing, to the wrong of her that merits all?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Is that the character of Algernon? Is he ſo undeſerving?

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Ah there, my friend, there is my terror; the deſtiny I dread; the man of all men living the moſt dangerous to my peace is Algernon.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Preſerve my Emily from him—ſave her from Algernon!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Is Algernon then born to be a curſe to both of us?

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Explain yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: He is your nephew, therefore I was ſilent, but if he's dangerous to your peace of mind, to mine he's fatal—in one word, the wound of which my hapleſs Lionel now languiſhes was given by the hand of Algernon.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Horrible wretch!—his murderer.—

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: I ſay not that; for modern courteſy gives not that name to duelliſts, and honour ſanctifies their bloody deeds.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Away with all ſuch honour! Truth diſavows it, nature revolts from it, religion denounces it—Oh! he is born to be my ſhame and torment.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Be patient for a while; ſuſpend your judgment.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: No, I regard a duelliſt with horror; I hold him as an agent of the enemy of mankind, ſent to diſturb ſociety, and rend the parent's and the widow's hearts aſunder: one action, one only action, and that a doubtful one, had met my ear in favour of that wretch whom I call nephew, and henceforth even that one I totally diſcredit, and renounce him.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Hold, I conjure you. In the midſt of wrath let us remember juſtice. I, like you, abhor a duelliſt profeſt; yet I am taught by long experience how to make allowances for younger ſpirits, and warmer paſſions, that will not ſubmit to meet the world's contempt, and ſcorn its prejudices.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Away! you talk this language by profeſſion; reaſon declares againſt it.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p:
Reaſon demands that we ſhould pauſe
in judgment. When two men draw their ſwords upon each other, reaſon will tell us one muſt be to blame; but ere we ſix the blame upon that one, juſtice decrees that we ſhould hear them both.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: What ſays your nephew? He will ſpeak the truth.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: I ſhould expect he would; yet I'll not wholly truſt to any man's report againſt another in his own cauſe; and in this ſentiment my nephew honourably coincides, for he declines all anſwer to my queſtions, and will ſtate nothing to affect or criminate his antagoniſt—Hah! who is this?

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Go, go! I did not ſend for you.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I know it; but I wiſh to ſpeak in private with Sir Oliver Montrath.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: With me? Who is this man? I do not know him. Is he one of your ladyſhip's domeſtics?

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: No; he made offer of his ſervices, but upon talking with him I perceiv'd he had a liſt of grievances to ſtate, and not being then at leiſure, I believe I told him he might wait your coming, and make his ſuit to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: And ſo he may—his looks plead in his cauſe. Is it your wiſh to ſpeak with me, young man?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Alone?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Alone, if you'll permit it.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Freely; and when I can command my time, it ſhall be your's. I'll call for you.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I ſhall attend your ſummons.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: I'm curious what this man can have to tell me. Do you conjecture?

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: There is a myſtery about him. He ſays he is a gentleman by birth, and ſo far I believe him. Of what he had to tell beſides I wav'd the hearing, but offer'd him relief: that did not ſeem his object, nor was it mine to take a gentleman into my ſervice. But you will know the whole—ſhall we adjourn and ſee what is become of Emily?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: With all my heart; and hope the mournful ſubject of our laſt interview may be no more reviv'd.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: So! whence come you? who are you? what's your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Sir, I don't know you.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Not know me? that's much. You muſt be new indeed.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Are you that worthy gentleman Mr. Earling?

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: I am the very perſon.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Heaven reward you! Your fame is ſounded forth thro' all the county.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Are you not hir'd to wait on Miſs Fitzallan?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: No, Sir, my character don't ſeem to recommend me to the Lady Cypreſs. If you wou'd ſpeak for me 'twou'd make my fortune.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: How can I ſpeak for you, whom I don't know?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: 'Twou'd be as eaſy as to ſpeak againſt me.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: But I do neither; I have no concern with you or with your character.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Indeed! they told me you was famous for it.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: For what is it I'm famous?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: For ſpeaking about characters you've no concern with; therefore I pray you, ſir, take mine in hand, and do me juſtice. I ſuſpect ſome villain has cruelly defam'd me.—Doesn't an action lie for that at law?

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Go! you're a fool; begone!

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I am a fool to aſk a knave for juſtice.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Knave! do you call me knave? I'll trounce you, ſirrah! I'll blow you to the moon, audacious beggar! Ah, maſter Doctor, do you know that raſcal?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: I know ſeveral raſcals, but which of them do you mean?

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: That impudent new comer, that mad fellow, that dares to inſult me in my lady's houſe.— Call me a knave indeed, and to my face—did you ever hear ſuch inſolence?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Never, never: If he had only ſaid it behind your back, why 'twere but quid for quo; it would have paſs'd; but to your face—Oh monſtrous!

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: I'll ſet him in the ſtocks; I'll have his ears nailed to the whipping poſt.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: No, don't do that; if whipping-poſts had ears, they'd hear the cries of thoſe that are tied to them, and pity them.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p:
Pooh! you're as great a fool as he methinks:
I've done with you.—Look to yourſelf, Sir Ga •• ipot, your reign will not be long on this ground, take my word for it.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: There, there, there! I'm blown up, ouſted, all is over with me. Thought to have had my lady's cuſtom till her death—perceive now ſhe will be one of the few patients that out live my preſcriptions.— Oh fine work, fine work!

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: How now, friend Scud; what ails you?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Friend! call me fool. I'm ruin'd by my friendſhip. You've play'd the devil's dance with that damn'd lawyer, and ſet him whip and ſpur upon my back.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Why that's his proper place: back-biting is his trade.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: And what's my trade, do you think? where ſhall I drive it? my gallipots may grow into the ſhelves for everlaſting, if I'm to be made the cat's-paw of your ſchemes and fooliſh Jenny's—but I'll go tell my lady all about you.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: No, no, you'll not do that, my little Scud.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: I'll tell you what I won't do—loſe my cuſtomer.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Aye, but conſider what an ornament your ears are to your head, and you'll loſe them incontinently if you betray me.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: My ears indeed! look to your own; the lawyer has ſworn to nail them to the whipping poſt. I've got a wig, ſo have not you, my maſter. Beſides, I'm not quite certain but my lady's cuſtom will be the greater loſs.—She takes a world of phyſic.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Who talks of phyſic? I've the beſt of medicines—a caſe of old canary, which my lady has order'd us to tap, and drink a welcome to our noble gueſt, Sir Oliver Montrath.—I've put my lips to it: 'tis ſupernacu •• m.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: I ſee you have; I ſee 'tis ſupernaculum, for ſome of it has got under your wig already.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: My wig, no, no, Dame Dorothy ſet that awry with a kind cuff o'the ear.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: You put your lips to her too, it ſhould ſeem.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Perhaps I did, but that's all buckram, Doctor. Ah Henry, give me your hand. Stand faſt, my gallant hearts; lo, where ſhe comes again, a portly ſail right on upon our convoy. My life upon't, ſhe's bound to the Canaries.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Oh thou raſh youth, thou haſt undone thyſelf. Earling has vow'd thy ruin.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: He has vow'd my ruin too, and that is one of the few vows that he will keep religiouſly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Ah, he's a carnal man; he'll ſwallow up this caſtle and it's fortunes.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: I hope the turrets of it will ſtick by the way, and choak him. He ſha'n't ſwallow the canary in it however; we'll be beforehand with him at that ſport.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: I would I had the cooking of one doſe for him. I wiſh he'd ſwallow that. It ſhou'd be a ſettler.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
What has he done by Harry Algernon? There's malice for you; there's a batch of miſchief,
blaſted his character, garbled his fortune, and turn'd my lady's heart to ſtone againſt him.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Flint, iron, adamant—I told her ſo— Madam, ſaid I, the gentleman is wrong'd; the neighbours, where he lives, all give him a good word, the gentry love him, his father doats on him, the poor adore him: there is but one bad character 'twixt him and your attorney—Judge you, ſaid I, which party it belongs to.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Did you ſay this?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Then you're an honeſt fellow.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: I know that well enough. Yes, I did ſay it.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: How did ſhe take it?

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: As ſhe takes your phyſic—gulp'd and made wry faces; but it went down.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: I hope 'twill ſtay by her.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: I hope it will, and when we've drank confuſion to attornies, I'll deal her out another doſe a little ſtronger. Damn it!—no, hold, I will not ſwear—I'll do it coolly—come, we'll call a council in the Canaries.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Agreed; I'll drink myſelf into a little courage, and have a word with the old laſs myſelf.

sp.speaker: Simon.
sp.p: Come on, my hearts! Henry, conduct the lady. You may ſolicit her fair hand in ſafety. Jerry and I have wigs.

div.stage: Lady CYPRESS, EMILY, Sir OLIVER MONTRATH, EARLING.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Now, Emily, you ſee what miſery that wicked man has brought upon us all.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I'm ſorry for Sir Oliver's misfortune.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: I hope you have alſo pity for the ſufferer.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I truſt I have for all that merit it.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: I'm ſure Miſ's Emily will not attempt to extenuate the guilt of ſuch an action.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: You may be ſure I never will defend a guilty perſon, knowing him for ſuch; be you as careful how you criminate an abſent man, till you have proofs againſt him. To Sir OLIVER. Sir, you are ſilent; I ſhould wiſh to know if you have any thing to urge againſt him.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Nothing, my dear, I'm liſtening with attention, and therefore ſilent. I ſhould be ſorry were you leſs unwilling to give up your opinion of a man who render'd you ſuch ſervice.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: What ſervice? Earling, you have heard the ſtory; let us hear what you have to ſay upon it.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: If Miſs Fitzallan will ſuffer me to put a ſimple queſtion to her.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: By all means; put your queſtion.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: When Mr. Algernon, by happy chance, came in ſo opportunely to her reſcue, can Miſs Fitzallan ſay what brought him thither ſo far from his own home?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I never aſk'd what caus'd him to be there, nor did he tell me.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p:
We'll call it then a very happy chance without a cauſe, or a moſt fortunate preſentiment that ſomewhere in that grove there would be found a damſel in the power of ſome vile ruffian, whom he was doom'd to reſcue. Some people might ſuppoſe
this a colluſion, but Miſs Fitzallan can remove all doubts by telling us who was the villain that offer'd her that violence.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Can you do this, my Emily?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Did Mr. Algernon know who he was?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: I do not think he did.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Did he ſecure his perſon?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: No; his care was wholly turn'd to me▪ the man he left upon the ground, and, as it ſeem'd, diſabled.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: I have done: I leave it to the court to judge.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: A barefac'd trick. It is too palpable.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Who can ſay that?—Let Mr. Algernon ſpeak for himſelf.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Speak!

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Aye, you have ſpoke, and ſhould not he? That's juſtice, is it not?

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Did you always find it ſo where you have been, Sir Oliver?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Whether I found it ſo or not, I felt it.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Now, Mr. Earling, you may put thoſe queſtions, you've preſs'd on me, to Mr. Algernon. Perhaps he'll anſwer them.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Emily, Emily, you forget yourſelf.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
Madam, I ſhould, if I forbore to ſpeak, when charges ſuch as theſe are urg'd againſt an abſent, therefore a defenceleſs, man. You have not allow'd him to approach you, madam; this gentleman, equally unknown to him, prejudges him at once; he is ingenious to find out bad motives for good actions; there's not a virtue in the human
heart but may be metamorphos'd by ſuch cunning into a vice. Sir Oliver has ſaid, and ſaid it in the language of a hero—Let Mr. Algernon ſpeak for himſelf.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: And I repeat thoſe words.—Let him be heard!—However circumſtances bear againſt him, and wretched tho' he has made me, ſtill I hold it matter of conſcience never to prejudge, however ſtrong the grounds of my ſuſpicion.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Sir Oliver, we do not think alike, and therefore with your leave we'll cut this ſubject ſhort. Emily will retire—a little recollection will be uſeful to ſhew the error of ſome raſh opinions and amend them. Go, child, remember I have now a right to look for the obedience of a daughter.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And I to expect the mildneſs of a mother.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: And now, Sir Oliver, with your permiſſion I will diſpatch a little buſineſs with my agent, and leave you to fulfil your promiſe to that young man, who I perceive is waiting to approach you. Follow me, Mr Earling.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: See here a ſample of the bleſſings of dependance!—Poor orphan Emily, 'tis now my turn to prove that I am worthy to be call'd friend of thy gallant father.
Oh! come in, come in, young man! I promis'd you a hearing, and I'll make good my word; but as my mind is preſs'd with many matters, be ſhort and to the point.—

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I will. Your nephew has had an affair with Mr. Algernon, and is wounded. You have viſited him no doubt. Has he related to you the particulars of that unpleaſant buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Before I anſwer, let me know who it is that queſtions me.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: My father lives upon the lands of Sir George Algernon, and I have ſome acquaintance with his ſon, the perſon whoſe unlucky chance it was to wound your nephew.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: And what's your motive for the queſtion that you now put to me?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I am no ſtranger to your character, and if you know the circumſtances of that duel, I truſt you will not ſuffer Mr. Earling to miſrepreſent them to the Lady Cypreſs.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliver.
sp.p: Certainly I ſhou'd not, if I knew the truth, ſuffer it to be diſguis'd; but I have no particulars from my nephew. The affair remains a myſtery. Can you develope it?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: If Lady Cypreſs will permit me to ſtay this night, as ſhe has promis'd, and you can bring me to an explanation with her in your preſence, I can ſo far elucidate this myſtery, that if you ſtill perſiſt to trace it home you ſhall have full poſſeſſion of the means.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: I hardly ſhould expect it at your hands; nor where my nephew's honour is concern'd ſhall I be eaſily induc'd to liſten to other evidence than that of facts, incontrovertibly atteſted, and (I am free to ſay) admitted on his part.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: 'Tis to ſuch facts and ſuch authorities I ſhall appeal.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: And do you mean to criminate my nephew?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Pardon me, ſir, I have no other meaning but to declare the truth.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Have you the means to know it? Was you preſent at the rencontre?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: If it appears that I have not the means to know the truth, or knowingly diſguiſe it, treat me as I deſerve; I'm in your hands.

sp.speaker: Sir Oliv.
sp.p: Well, ſir, I'll urge no further queſtions on you, but uſe my intereſt with the Lady Cypreſs to procure you the interview you wiſh. Now fail not on your part: you know me, ſir; I truſt to you unknown.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Poor as I ſeem, I have a ſoul within that never yet was tainted by diſhonour.

div.stage: Lady CYPRESS, EMILY FITZALLAN, and EARLING.

sp.speaker: Lady CYPRESS.
sp.p: WELL, child, I have here the inſtrument, that makes you rich above the dreams of avarice. I have not executed it, for that depends on you; I have not cancell'd it, becauſe this gentleman, your ſteady friend, has interceded with me to recal you once more to recollection and atonement.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: For what muſt I atone?

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: For your intemperate defence of Algernon. Guilty or innocent, no more of him! Where I beſtow my fortune I expect to find no oppoſition to my will in the diſpoſal of it.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: What is your will in that reſpect?

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: This is my will—If Lionel Montrath ſurvives his wound, he is the man I deſtine for my heireſs. To this if you declare inſtant aſſent I ſhall as inſtantly confirm this paper; if not, I cancel it, and caſt you off.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Not all the world cou'd bribe me to do that, before I know which is the offending party. What baſeneſs, what ingratitude were mine, to give give my hand to him that wrong'd the brave preſerver of my life and honour!

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Obſtinate girl, you have no ſuch preſerver. Have not I told you it was mere colluſion?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Madam, you have; but I am not convinc'd, becauſe you told me ſo by your attorney, not from your own knowledge and conviction.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: What will convince you?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Proof well eſtabliſhed, and all parties heard.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: You to make terms that call'd yourſelf my daughter! Where is your duty?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
Inviolate, unbroken.—I ſhall ever bear you reſpect and true devotion for your goodneſs; but no parent, no patroneſs, not even my father, to whoſe awful ſpirit I now appeal, cou'd have the power, or cou'd poſſeſs the right to tear away affections from my heart, which honour, gratitude,
have planted there, or force me to conſpire with that bad man in ſtripping Algernon of fame and fortune, and fixing artifice, deceit, and murder upon a man ſo near to you in blood, in nature ſo abhorrent of thoſe crimes.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: You are mad; I have done with you; I caſt you off. Now, Mr. Earling, take away your papers; they, or the thankleſs object they allude to, muſt be entirely chang'd before I ſign them.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Miſs Emily, it grieves me to the heart to have heard what now has paſs'd. Indeed you wrong me if you ſuppoſe I am the author of this fatal breach. I am no otherwiſe the enemy of Mr. Algernon than as I am your friend; in very truth I'm not his enemy,

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Sir, for your enmity to Mr. Algernon, and ſo much of your friendſhip as flows from it, I pray you let them go together; I have no uſe for either.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Do you ſcorn me becauſe I pity you?

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: You pity me! There cannot be that ſtate of human wretchedneſs which cou'd reduce me to accept your pity. I wonder you can waſte your time with one, who neither courts your favour, fears your power, nor credits your profeſſions.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: Well, haughty madam, I have been a friend, and I can be a foe.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: My Emily, my angel, what is this I've heard? Diſcarded, diſinherited—and for your generoſity to me.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p:
Yes, Algernon, I'm poor, but free. I was
a priſoner in a gaudy cage, where they wou'd fain have taught me to call names, and whiſtle to a tune of Earling's making; but being a bad bird, and obſtinate, my keeper let me fly; and now I've got the wide world for my portion, and nothing but my own ſmall wits to truſt to for picking up a living.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Fly to me, perch on my breaſt, for in my heart you'll find both ſhelter and affection.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Ah, that is generous, gallant, like yourſelf; but 'tis not yet a time for me to hear you. The aſylum that you offer is attack'd, the very citadel of your life and honour is beſieg'd by aſſailants, and you muſt beat them off, my hero, or I have ſacrific'd myſelf to ruin without the enjoyment of that honeſt pride which glories in the cauſe for which it ſuffers.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Doubt me not, Emily, the ſhield of truth covers my breaſt, and I'm invulnerable.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Earling accuſes you of a colluſion with my unknown aſſailant in the wood—

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: I'm arm'd againſt that charge.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: And for your wounding of Montrath, he calls it aſſaſſination—There I ſhou'd fear you are not ſo well arm'd, having no ſeconds to appeal to, and therefore more expos'd to his attack.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Let him come on; at all points I defy him. Now, my ſweet advocate, repoſe in peace, and wait the event.

sp.speaker: Emily.
sp.p: Farewell! If I am ruin'd in the cauſe of truth I'll not regret the ſacrifice.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Heroic Emily, how I adore you—Hah! Jerry, whence come you?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: From the Canaries, where the illuſtrious major-domo governs, and drinking is a duty by the laws of the ſage Solon of the cellars, the profound Diogenes of the tubs, of whoſe academy I am a member.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: You've not betray'd me in your cups, I hope.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Betray'd you! no, if you had fir'd the houſe, burnt the old lady in it, and violated the virgin purity of dame Buckram, I'd not betray you—D—n it! I ſcorn a ſneaker; I loath him worſe than phyſic—Go on, my boy, and fear not— I am ſteady.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Pretty well for that. You've had a ſip or two with honeſt Simon.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Simon's a fiſh; Dame Buckram is a leech; fills where ſhe faſtens, and delights in ſuction: I honour her for her abſorbent qualities, and I pronounce that they are ſilly apes and ignoramuſſes that ſay wine gets into the head—'tis falſe—I ſay it gets into the heart; it drives ill humour, melancholy, treaſon, and a whole gang of cowardly companions out of a man, as a carminative does crudities and indigeſtion: it wou'd have ſet my conſtitution clear, only there's one thing ſticks—

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: What's that, my honeſt fellow? Out with it.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Why then 'tis jealouſy—and that you know is a confounded ſpaſm—

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Away with it at once! Why, man, you don't know half your happineſs; you have the beſt wife in the country—Oh! if you cou'd have heard her pine for you laſt night; ſhe wou'dn't hear of comfort—

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Indeed, indeed! May I believe you, ſquire? May I be ſure I'm not the horned beaſt?

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: None of my making, Jerry, on my honour.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: O jubilate! then I kick the clouds. Good bye, good bye to you. Let me embrace you. All luck attend you. I'm going to my lady; if I can throw in a provocative to ſtir her in your favour I will do it; I will upon my ſoul! Good bye to you!

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Stop, Jerry; hold your hand, my gallant fellow! I am too much your friend to let you go to Lady Cypreſs in your preſent ſtate. Why, man, you are tipſey.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Say drunk, and you'll not ſay more than is true; but then it is I cure my patients; when I am only ſober I let them cure themſelves.

sp.speaker: Alg.
sp.p: Well, get you gone; I am not bound to find reaſon for him that will not keep his own.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Come hither, Rachel, I wou'd ſpeak with you. When I promoted you to be about the perſon of Miſs Emily Fitzallan, it was becauſe I ſaw you was attached to her, and I was willing to do her a grace by thus preferring you. If you muſt now fall back into your ſtation, it is not that I have withdrawn my favour from you, but from your miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: I know it, madam; all your people know it, for Mr. Earling has announc'd it to us; but I muſt beg your ladyſhip to excuſe me if I decline all ſervice but Miſs Emily's.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: What ſhou'd enable her to keep a ſervant?

sp.speaker: Rachel.
sp.p: Then ſhe will ſtand in the more need of me; I'll work my fingers to the bone to ſerve her. Your ladyſhip may turn me from your doors, but I will ſay that Mr. Earling's a baſe cruel man, and when he has driven all your relations from you, your ladyſhip will find your houſe a deſert, and nothing but a villain left within it.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Out of my ſight! begone! Such inſolence is not to be endur'd—yet Earling is to blame to publiſh this to all my family. So! what comes next?

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: Madam, I've ſerv'd your ladyſhip too long to bear the arrogance of Mr. Earling. I beg to be diſcharg'd; I'll not live in the houſe with one who drives Miſs Emily out of your doors, tells ſuch monſtrous lies of Mr. Algernon, and ſets your ladyſhip againſt all your friends and relations.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Who made you a judge in matters that concern me only? When you are cool I'll hear you. I know you have been junketing and caballing with Rachel Williams, and the reſt of them—prythee retire!

sp.speaker: Buck.
sp.p: That's what I mean to do, and others beſide me, or I'm miſtaken. We reſpect your ladyſhip, but we can't put up with your attorney.

div.stage: EARLING enters whilſt this is ſaying.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: There, Mr. Earling, you hear what is ſaid againſt you — Murmurs, complaints, invectives from all quarters—

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p:
No wonder, when that Henry Scudamore,
whom I ſuſpect to be a ſecret agent of your unworthy nephew's, ſets them on to blacken and arraign me. Madam, he has had the inſolence to give me the worſt of names.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Then give him his diſmiſſion—ſend him away at once.

sp.speaker: Earl.
sp.p: It ſhall be done.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Oh, that Sir Oliver had poſtpon'd his viſit to his nephew but one hour!
Ah, prythee, prythee, do not plague me now. What brings you hither?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Duty, my lady, duty—want to hear how the draughts have agreed.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: 'Tis plain how your draughts have agreed—the operation's viſible; no matter about mine.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Oh pardon me, there is great matter— ſpar'd for no pains—employ'd the beſt of drugs— hope I have given content—but rumours ſly—no parrying defamation—a man may be accus'd behind his back, and who can ſtand it?

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: What rumours do you allude to? Who has accus'd you?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: I don't know who may have accus'd me, my lady; I wiſh to heaven I cou'd ſay I have accus'd nobody.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: Oh dear, madam, I am troubled with the heart-ache; I have a lacerated conſcience.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: You have a loaded head, I perceive; more wine in it than wit.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: True, my lady; it is ſo full I can no longer hide the truth within it. Out it muſt come, and true it is, I have ſlander'd Mr. Algernon. He ſav'd my life, and I have ſtabb'd his character.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: You don't know what you ſay— you're tipſey.

sp.speaker: Scud.
sp.p: I wiſh I had been tipſey when I ſpoke of him; then I ſhou'd have told the truth.

sp.speaker: Lady Cyp.
sp.p: Go your ways; get you gone! a man that is in two ſtories ſhou'd be credited for neither. You made him out to me a compound of all vices.

sp.speaker: Scud.
